Posts.Content: Hi Elaine I replied to the initial thread as I was in a similar position to you. I'm 45. I empathise with you as its such a difficult decision to make, after all..... Who wants chemo ??!! I was told that if chemo improves outcome by 3% or less its generally not recommended. If it improves prognosis by more than 5%, your told you should have it. It's the boundary between 3% and 5% that's the grey area. You are at the lower end of this scale. It's such a hard, and personal decision. I didn't find it easy at all. I opted for chemo, which was my oncologist recommendation....... I've done 2 sessions and it's hard, but doable. My mums friend (who is a nurse) had a grade 3 lump, and opted not to have chemo. She was 56 at the time. She just celebrated her 5 year anniversary and is very happy with her decision. It's not a "one size fits all" solution. The most important thing is that YOU are happy with what you decide. I thought about my family circumstances (I have a disabled son), the support I have now to help me get through this (I'm lucky, I have great family and friends), my health (otherwise good) and how I felt about he possibility of putting my life on hold for 5 months (it hasnt quite come to that!) Please feel free to pm me with any questions you have, I'm not an expert but have been in your shoes You will make the right choice. Sending you virtual hugs, Sarah xxxxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had to choose whether or not to have Chemo?? Confused

Posts.Content: Hi, I had this with FEC. üòîI was so bad I was taken off of it. üòùThe only thing that eventually seemed to make it better was Stemitil. They are for travel sickness, and I had them by injection when I had fEC but take them in tablet form now. Ask your oncologist if they might help. I do have Emend, but found that domperindome didn't help at all. S xxx
Posts.Title: Does this sea-sickness feeling go away?

Posts.Content: Hi Flower, my heart goes out to you. I know exactly what you mean. I too was fit, like you ran 10k two or three times a week and enjoyed half marathons. I wasn't overweight, non smoker, drank in moderation etc..... I did self exams fairly regularly because I guess I always thought "why not me?" thank goodness I did. I knew when something wasn't right, even when the consultant and surgeon couldnt feel anything to worry about. I've had friends who genuinely don't know what to say, and get it wrong.... And others who are seemingly trying to avoid me, which I find really upsettingüò¢ One lady i know (althoigh not well) said "were you scared when you found out it was cancer?" duh!!! On the other hand, I've had some real surprises. People who I don't know well actively offering me a lift to hospital, to do housework or just to come and keep me company when I'm down. It's a funny thing, certainly seems to bring out the very best and worst in people we know. Try not to dwell on the comments your friend made, they were insensitive and upsetting.... But focus that energy on getting well enough to get your running shoes back on üèÉüèÉ S xxxx
Posts.Title: so annoyed with crass comments

Posts.Content: Key features, love your links..... I'm loving my Buffs (Morphs) with chiffon wraps in a turban style. Your pictures have given me more ideas... Thanksüòä Yvonne, glad I'm not the only one who did that party trick!! It was fun whilst it lasted, but backfired a bit when my hair took to actually blowing away in the wind... It was me who was a bit freaked out then! üòß X
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, don't apologise for posting. I really feel for you. This journey has so many twists and turns and to have your diagnosis changed is such a huge shock. I have IDC and was given the choice if chemo. My lump was a lot bigger than yours (2.1cm) so the fact that it's invasive doesn't becessary mean that you'll need to go through that. You're not alone. I would give the helpline a call, please don't sit there on your own until the nurse calls. The team you with the questions you need to ask. I'm sending you a big virtual gentle (((hug))) S xxxxx
Posts.Title: Just got call from oncologist not good news

Posts.Content: Hi Carol In answer to your question earlier about whether I had chemo..... Not yet. I have until 6th August to decide. The main reason it is of any benefit to me is my age. I'm 45. After weighing up the pros and cons, I will be having it. I don't know what the protocol is in France, ie do they routinely give chemo even if there is only a potentially tiny benefit, or whether they do tests (like Oncotest dx in USA) which analysis the tumour and gives a much more accurate indication of the need for chemo, before recommending it??? In UK there seems to be clear guideline es as to when it's recommended, and then a category where people are 'borderline' ie small benefit, but not essential and the patient gets to choose..... Like me It's no bad thing, but I think that many countries err on the side of caution and 'overtreat'. Try not to worry, like the other ladies said your outlook looks very positive, its probably a very cautious approach........and if you get the offer of chemo it's just more ammunition you can choose to throw at it! Hope this helps, let us know how you get on S xxxx
Posts.Title: Just got call from oncologist not good news

Posts.Content: Hi Babs, sorry to hear how low you were...... But glad you're feeling a bit brighter now. üòä My friend (who is a nurse) said that sometimes he anaesethic can make you feel really low a few days after the operation...... A sort of delayed reaction. I don't know if that's true or if she said it to make e feel better on one of my 'down days'. I'm thinking that, before all this happened to me, I had 'good' days and 'not so good' days..... It's just now they seem more extreme. It's as if the volume has been turned up on my emotions. My appointment with the oncologist was cancelled today as my results from USA weren't ready. He's said he'll see me Thursday, so hopefully I'll have a plan for chemo then...... Ive got everything crossed for you for Friday, please let me know how you get on S xxx
Posts.Title: had a nice weekend but feeling realy low today

Posts.Content: Key features, love your links..... I'm loving my Buffs (Morphs) with chiffon wraps in a turban style. Your pictures have given me more ideas... Thanksüòä Yvonne, glad I'm not the only one who did that party trick!! It was fun whilst it lasted, but backfired a bit when my hair took to actually blowing away in the wind... It was me who was a bit freaked out then! üòß X
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Hi Earls, glad it seems to be going ok. I too was very very sick on my first FEC, despite having Emend from outset. I was taken off FEC and put on TC for the next 5 doses as as result. The T is Taxatore or Docetaxel! I had my new cocktail last Weds and was given Emend by IV again. I wasn't sick!!! I had the one off injection, which I did myself (I'm fine with needles, just a big baby taking tablets!!!) I was fine until late Friday evening, day 3, when I started to get a bit achy. Saturday wasn't great as I was achy, constipated and very very tearful. But Sunday, day 5 was the worst day by a mile. I ached in bones I never knew I had.... Didn't get out of bed.... Even my teeth hurt!! But the weird thing is, when I woke on Monday the aching had gone! Completely disappeared. I still had vile taste and a blinding headache.... But otherwise felt relatively ok. I have to say, it wasn't a nice experience, but better than FEC for me! Hope ou sail through it with few side effects...... Let us know how you get on. Hugs Sarah xxx
Posts.Title: 1ST DOCETAXEL YESTERDAY

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, Jellytot, how scary...hope you are getting better xx Carol, you are right. I had a lovely day Tuesday. Went to a 'Look good, Fell better' session, did a bit of shopping, popped into work for an Hour..... Weds I made it to the sofa, just! I really underestimated how much it's taken out of me. Taking things a bit more steady now, which is Sooooooooo frustrating!!! Sarah x
Posts.Title: 1ST DOCETAXEL YESTERDAY

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, chemo does funny things to us for sure. I can understand your fear, I was worried my chemo wasn't working because my hair wasn't falling out...... Then when it did yesterday, I was a sobbing wreck! I expect the red patches are some sort of reaction to the chemicals in your body, bit like the boil that's appeared on my chin this morning - its the size of a bean! The only way you'll know for sure is to talk to the oncologist tomorrow, which I know doesn't help..... In the meantime why don't you give the Mac nurses or your BCN a call as they've a wide experience and will be able to reassure you. As for the chemo not shrinking your lump this time, I expect it has shrunk but as it gets smaller the shrinkage won't be as noticeable to you. 10% shrinkage in a 10cm lump is 1cm...... 10% of a 3cm lump is only 3mm...... Much harder to detect the reduction without a scan. I hate to think of you on your own, upset. Please give the nurses a call and talk to them. FEC is ferocious, I'm sure it's still blasting away the enemy within. Huge hugs, Sarah xüòòüòò
Posts.Title: really scared

Posts.Content: Hi Nikki, glad you got such positive news.... The light at the end of the tunnel just got brighter:-) So pleased for you, S xxxx
Posts.Title: Feeling upbeat today

Posts.Content: Hi, I reacted badly to my first round of FEC, despite being on all sorts of anti emetics, including Emend by IV prior to the chemo being administeredüòñ My Oncologist has recommended changing me to TC (Taxotere (docetaxel) and Cyclophosphamide) for the next 5 cycles. He explained that it's equally effective, and is more commonly used in place of FEC in USA, Canada, New Zealand. I'm happy I'm changing as, although the side effects don't sound great, they should be easier to control (for me) than the sickness FEC subjected me toüòù Has anyone else been on this regime who can share their experiences?? I'm feeling a little anxious üòí S xxxx
Posts.Title: Anyone experience of TC chemo (Taxotere and Cyclophosphamide)????...

Posts.Content: Hi Squirrelüòä TAX was so much easier than FEC for me. In fact I couldn't have FEC after my first dose because I reacted so badly to it. üòù I didn't have to go into hospital - I had a Neulasta injection the day after each chemo. It's supposed to be more effective than the multiple injections at keeping your neutrophil levels up. But it is expensive so lots of areas won't prescribe it..... Grr, postcode lottery. But ask about it! üòâ None of the side effects were debilitating on their own, although it want always easy having them simultaneously.üòÅ I had 5 TAX, and finished on 28th Nov. It was ok. ReallyüòÑ Luvvieüòö Sorry, no paragraphs on iPad....tried to use emoticons instead!
Posts.Title: 2 more FEC then 4 tax, i am in pieces worrying

Posts.Content: Winston, gotta say, your laughter and good spirit is infectious üòÑxxxxx
Posts.Title: Bone and CT scans

Posts.Content: Aw SaxxyD, what a lovely post üòÄ So happy for you, glad you're through the tunnel and making plans....... I just keep thinking, that'll be me in the springüòÄüòÄ Xxxxx
Posts.Title: Finished Rads now Tamoxifen!!!

Posts.Content: Good Luck ladies. Óêò I had my WLE and SNB 3 weeks ago today. I cannot believe how well it's healed and how little pain I experienced post surgery. It was uncomfortable at times, but lots of pillows in bed, keeping up the painkillers and religiously doing the post op exercises really worked for me. Most people do feel so much happier when they know the journey's started and the beast has been evicted! Let us all know how you get on S xx
Posts.Title: MX tomorrow and lymph node clearance....

Posts.Content: I haven't tried it, although I know Key Features has. üòä Hopefully she'll be along later and let you know her experience. S xxx
Posts.Title: Fasting Before & After Chemo

Posts.Content: Congratulations, I'm halfway through and am starting to see that glimmer at the end of the tunnel. Hope you get through this last round with ease. Xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Just had my last Chemo!!

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel, Just to say I'm thinking of you too. Although I didn't have the appointment from hell that you encountered last time around, I do get terrified at my appointments..... I'm almost waiting for them to break the next bit of bad news to me. Hopefully you'll get much more positive news tomorrow, and your faith in the professionals will be someway to being restored. Hugs to you, a lot of us ladies will be 'virtually' holding your hand S xxüòò
Posts.Title: Terrified of ONC appt tomorrow :(

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone, I'm in the middle of chemo at the moment and am due to start radiotherapy just after Christmas. Ages ago we booked to go to CenterParcs with the children and some friends, mid Jan. I'm going to be towards the end of my radiotherapy, possibly still having it:-( Can you swim whilst in the middle of it, or very shortly after finishing?? If I am forced to sit out e pool sessions, I'm going to be gutted..... The thought of some time in the spa might compensate....... Could I do this?? I've not got any info so far on radiotherapy other than what I've picked up on this forum, so any advise appreciated. Thanks Sarah x Ps I've just realised why my posts never appear in paragraphs....... I'm using an iPad. Does anyone know how to do paragraphs using one?! It looks ok until I post it........
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy & swimming / spa

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel, Just to say I'm thinking of you too. Although I didn't have the appointment from hell that you encountered last time around, I do get terrified at my appointments..... I'm almost waiting for them to break the next bit of bad news to me. Hopefully you'll get much more positive news tomorrow, and your faith in the professionals will be someway to being restored. Hugs to you, a lot of us ladies will be 'virtually' holding your hand S xxüòò
Posts.Title: Terrified of ONC appt tomorrow :(

Posts.Content: Hi Kelzy You are brave and sensible. You would have been irresponsible to yourself (and your family) to take any additional risk with your health whilst battling this horrid disease. I admire you for doing the right thing for you. That takes courage. Also, you have helped the research - they now have sone information in the profile of someone who may refuse this treatment in the future, should it become available. This might help them decide who it is most appropriate for?! As for the 'rampaging' tumour..... I think we've all been anxious about that. The consultant assured me that these things have usually been there for years as opposed to months, and these lumps don't grow nearly as quickly as we imagine. I had all sorts of phantom pains and was imagining all sorts. The treatment should stop it in it's tracks. There are ladies on here who report their lumps shrinking loads through chemo, try not to worry. Good luck for your first session (I've not started yet, so cannot offer any words of wisdom) S xx
Posts.Title: Am i really awful?

Posts.Content: Poor you!! It sounds awful:-( You seem to be through it now though, and still a sense of humour!!!! Go girl!!! You can cheer me on come mid August ÓêÑ S x
Posts.Title: Hooray...and up she rises!

Posts.Content: Hi Anita I'm awake too, I has my first chemo yesterday and the steroids wont let my tired body sleepÓÅò I was assured that my lump was normal fiborous tissue, thankfully they did a biopsy to find it was invasive ductal cancer. My lump was 2.1cm and I was lucky that it could be taken away with a wide local excision. I had the choice of chemo because of my age (45) and I opted to have it. Whilst I know I'm lucky to not have to have a mastectomy, I honestly think the surgical procedure is the easiest part, although I do understand the phycologucal impact of losing your breast. Have you talked through all the pros and vows with your BCN, of having chemo first? I guess I'd want to know of there was any way of having a lesser operation if the lump continued to shrink to that extent. It sounds like it's hormone positive, which is a very good sign too.... It's responding to the drugs. I felt in turmoil, until yesterday really. Until I had that needle in my arm and I knew that my treatment was starting, there was always some uncertainty. You will feel better once your decision is made, and you will know it's the right decision for you. There will be others along in the morning with more relevant experience who can share with you, and the helpline is great for factual info. Be armed with all the questions you need answers to an speak to your BCN about your specific situation. You will be fine Sending hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: Its life Jim, but not as we know it

Posts.Content: I had my WLE and SNB on 11th July, results last Thursday (Grade 2, 2.1cm, ER/PR+, HER2 -ve, no nodes involved) I know I need radiotherapy and tamoxifen, but was 'borderline' for Chemo. I was told I had a choice! I guess I should feel lucky that I have a choice as lots of ladies don't, but what a choice to have to make. I've also been asked if I want to take part in a trial for Oncotype DX - its a test used in America which tests your tissue sample against 21 different factors and then asseses how beneficial chemo would be to you. The trial is to establish whether the patient finds the test useful in the decision making process as opposed to whether it is accurate in it's prediction etc (that's already been confirmed in USA) I've¬†spent the entire weekend fretting and worrying about all¬†this. I've been reading up on the side effects of chemo (long and short term), trawling old posts to find out how people have coped with chemo and if anyone else has been in the unenviable position of having to make a 'choice'. I met with the oncologist today to discuss it all. Long and the short of it, the 2 factors which place me in the borderline category are 1) the size of my¬† lump - it was just over the 2cm threshold and¬†2) my age, I'm considered young at 45. Chemo does add benefit to my prognisis over the longer term - statistically anyway, only a few % points, but still a benefit.¬† My gut feel is that I want to throw everything at this I can and don't want to be sat here in X years time, with a reaccurance and thinking that chemo might have made the difference. I've made my decision to¬†have chemo¬†and I will start on FEC at some point in August, irrespective of the Oncotype results - my lovely consultant said I didn't even need to know what they were if I didn't want to. (That was after I broke down in tears...)¬† He finished the meeting by saying that if he was in my position he would be doing the same as me. Strange - I've dreaded chemo since the moment I discovered my 'lump', and tonight for the first time in weeks, I feel calm..................................
Posts.Title: Chemo - decision made

Posts.Content: Phew! Just found this thread and I feel a bit better.... Had my first of 6 FEC on Weds last week. Reacted violently and was sick every 10 mins for over 12 hours. I'd been started on what the onc considered to be the 'best' anti emetics and he was concerned about my reaction. He wanted to see me today to discuss what we do for round 2. He has suggested changing the regime to Docetaxel for the next 5 sessions. Until today, I hadn't realised this was the same thing as Taxotere. Sorry if m a bit slow. I've read such awful things about it, that I was a bit worried. The onc assured me that it wouldn't / couldn't be as bad as what id experienced on FEC. I'm hoping he's right. I do feel a bit reassured finding this thread.... Hope you are all still don't well on it, and fingers crossed I find it just as doable. S xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal for me better than FEC

Posts.Content: That's a long time to have been waiting. Glad you've got your results and your plan is taking shape. Great to see you're maintaining a sense of humour, it is important and will help get you through this. S xxxxx
Posts.Title: results at last

Posts.Content: Brilliant Tinkers, reading your post has picked me up a little.üòä I'm not especially down, but I was told yesterday that m having to hange chemo regime as I reacted so badly o FEC. I'm going on something called TC (Docetaxel and Cyclophosphamide combo), so am feeling like I'm at the start of the chemo journey again.üòù Glad to hear such positivity about your picc line, I'm having mine on 3rd Sept in time for round 2! I'm so thrilled for you on getting through that bl@@dy tunnel, enjoy every moment of your new future,üòÉ Sarah xxx
Posts.Title: Finished my treatment today!

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, that's brilliant news.... You sound SO excited:-) I haven't been to work since being diagnosed on 3rd July, I've just had my second chemo. I popped into the office on Tuesday (complete with my trusted friend Mildred -wig!) and fired up my laptop. I cannot tell you how GOOD it made me feel. I felt as if a little bit of ME had reappeared! I cannot really do my normal job at the moment as it involved long hours and travelling, but im hoping i can make a valuable contribution doing what I'm able to commit to over the next few months. The best bit is it gives us something else to think about - the best medicine, I think. Hope it works out well, they obviously value you a lot. Sarah xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Might be going back to work :)

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, really pleased for you...... Sounds like a positive plan. So glad your feeling better about it all. Good luck with your chemo tomorrow:-) S x
Posts.Title: never thought would be so happy to have surgery!!

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, So glad you got a 'nice' onc.... It makes all the difference doesn't it? I've found that the one positive of chemo (apart from the fact that it's hopefully killing off any nasties) is that it's taken my mind off the bigger picture for a bit. I find myself in a cycle of being ill, focussing on feeling better, not looking forward to the next chemo, having chemo, being ill etc etc. Every so often I think about the bigger picture and the longer term, and it is scary stuff. I guess I think that there isn't much I can do about my prognosis, but what I can do make sure is that my children remember this time as a positive one, whatever the future may bring. That takes a lot of effort and distracts me, for sure! Try not to dwell on the oncologists words about the results of the scan. I'm sure there is a remote possiblility that the chemo hasn't worked as well as he'd have liked (any thing is possible), but it's probably very, very unlikely... he's just doing his job and dotting all i's and crossing all t's. I'm sending you a big virtual hug, brave lady, (((HUG))) Sarah xxx
Posts.Title: Onc appointment today, reality kicking in :(

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, that's brilliant news.... You sound SO excited:-) I haven't been to work since being diagnosed on 3rd July, I've just had my second chemo. I popped into the office on Tuesday (complete with my trusted friend Mildred -wig!) and fired up my laptop. I cannot tell you how GOOD it made me feel. I felt as if a little bit of ME had reappeared! I cannot really do my normal job at the moment as it involved long hours and travelling, but im hoping i can make a valuable contribution doing what I'm able to commit to over the next few months. The best bit is it gives us something else to think about - the best medicine, I think. Hope it works out well, they obviously value you a lot. Sarah xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Might be going back to work :)

Posts.Content: Mary, that sounds like the perfect treat. I've 4 sessions to go.... But have just worked out hat if all goes to plan, 3 weeks after my last session is my birthday.... And just before Christmas!!! Just thinking about that has made me feel SOooooo happyüòÄ
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, I'm halfway through tomorrow üòä I had 1 FEC üòùand will be having My second TC (Tax & cyclophosphomide) tomorrow. The Tax combo wasn't a walk in the park, but much better than FEC for me, so hopefully those of you moving onto it won't find it too bad. Clinging onto the fact that 3 weeks after my last chemo, will be my birthday week.... So rather than the nasty SEs kicking in, I'll have something to look forward toüòÄ Hope you ladies who've just finished get your mojo back soon, just take it easy. Hugs, S xxxxx
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Eider, big (((hugs))) x I'm not much further in the journey than you but I can relate to the ever changing diagnosis. I think the scariest thing is that it doesn't inspire you with confidence...... If they got that wrong, what else are they missing, and where will it end? I think I've come to the conclusion that it's a journey. Everyone's paths are different and at each junction there's a signpost where we find out a little bit more..... At some point the signpost says 'treatment plan'. Until you get there you're still in limbo and in that horrible place where your worst fears are at the forefront of your mind. I wish I had the magic formula to make the waiting easier.....I kept busy to distract me. It didn't work 100% but I did get there. I'm still waiting on some final results which were due yesterday but delayed..... But they're not as significant as those early stage ones so im a bit calmer. I have everything crossed for you, it will be ok - they're being thorough and main sure you get the best possible treatment. Let us know how you get on S xxxüòòüòò
Posts.Title: Different day, different diagnosis. Now it is HER2+

Posts.Content: Sascha, your post made me think....... I've not really allowed myself to think about the end of the tunnel yet because the light there seems such a long way off. But, Clare's answer is perfect for me. I want things to go back to how they were. I will be a different person though, I can't fail to be, but hopefully it'll just enable me to take less for granted and enjoy the life I've been given. Sarah xx
Posts.Title: When do you graduate to being a BC SURVIVOR and stop being a patient...

Posts.Content: Hi Kittycat What a lovely post, perfectly summarises the light at the end of my own tunnel..... I'm going to bookmark this so I can re-read it one of my darker moments, it's inspirational:-) Go girl, you've made it through!!! Hugs, S xx
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: I ad the oncotype DX test through a NHS trial - The trial is to assess whether people find it useful in making a decision if they are borderline for chemo. Although my score was smack on the border for low / intermediate risk, i chose to have chemo. Id already decided to gave chemo so he test results would've confirmed my decision either way, i guess. It was hard, but I'm now halfway through rads and I'm glad i did it all.
Posts.Title: Chemo - Should I have it or not?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. Perhaps I should be celebrating, but I'm getting a bit concerned that my chemo isn't working. I had my first chemo FEC on 15th August, and bang on day 15 my hair started to fall out, in clumps. I had very, very thick hair.... Lots of it. I shaved it to #1 and it continued to malt everywhere, especially in the shower. I was taken off FEC due to my reaction to it, and put on Docetaxel / cyclophosphomide (TC) for the next 5 cycles. Since my first TC (5th Sept) my hair is no longer shedding. I have a very sparse covering a bit like action man! But if I tug at it, it's firmly in place. Weird. I shoul be pleased, but am wondering if it means my chemo isn't being effective.¬† Has anyone any similar experience? Sarah x
Posts.Title: Hair.... Still here!?

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha, You're someone who has been diagnosed with breast cancer. Fact. You belong to this forum. Fact. I think it takes great courage to make a choice over the treatment you have. I have been offered chemo, and have decide that for me, it's the right choice. I'm fortunate that I'm otherwise healthy. If I wasn't I wouldn't have made that choice. I think you've been very honest with yourself and have researched something that is the right thing for you. Not everyone would be strong enough to do that. With regards to 'do you belong', as I said in my first line. You SO do. You are facing the same dilemmas as all of us...... Your treatment may have different challenges, but are there any 2 people who have exactly the same reaction to chemo?????? And more importantly, on a mental and emotional level, we are all going through a similar journey and we all need somewhere to vent, cry and accept support on our way . I hope you get lots of replies to reassure you, S xxxxx
Posts.Title: Not sure if I still belong here or not?

Posts.Content: Aww Babs, I'm delighted for you.... Thats the best newsüòÑüòÑüòÑüòÑüòÑüòÑüòÑ As far as I'm aware they avoid the word 'cured' (don't know why) but you've probably got the same chance of getting bc again as the rest of the population who've nevr been through what you have, less maybe because you are on hormone therapy! I think it's defiantly cause for celebration üç∏,and the most fantastic wedding in a couple of weeks time Don't be a stranger to the site, I for one will miss your support Sarah xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: best onc app ever

Posts.Content: I'm just post third tax, having 5. üòÅ Am using Evonail which is used in France for people on docetaxel. So far, I can see a pink mark under my nails where chemo started, but absolutely no lifting or discolouration to the nail.üòÉ It's expensive at ¬£26 per bottle incl p&p online from Belgium, but worth it so far :-) üòä S xxxxx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel / Finger nails

Posts.Content: Hi Heidi, Welcome to the site, but sorry you find yourself here. You will find lots of people here, ready to 'hold your hand' as you go through the various stages of treatment. I'm afraid I don't know anything about metaplastic BC, but hopefully someone will be along soon who has experience of it. In the meantime, give the helpline a call. They are very knowledgeable and much more reliable than Dr Google!! Whilst it is tempting to use Google, try and resist as lots of the info there is out of date or just plain wrong. I hope you find out some more about your specic condition, soon. In he meantime, big hugs. Sarah x
Posts.Title: Metaplastic breast cancer

Posts.Content: Bumping this up for you :-) Also, if you type metaplastic into the search box (top right) there are a few old threads on it that might be helpful. I'd also try another reliable site www.breastcancercare.org.uk and use the search facility there to see if anyone has some information. Hoe this helps xxx
Posts.Title: Metaplastic breast cancer

Posts.Content: I was told the same as Anita when I asked. I think it's difficult because scams can only pick up masses of a certain size, so any stray cells are too minuscule to detect. Still ask your oncologist, but I think this might be the 'standard' in UK NHS. S xx
Posts.Title: How do I know if its spread?

Posts.Content: Hi Christine, I'm sorry I cannot offer any words of wisdom on the effects of FEC........ I have my first dose tomorrow! What I do know is that this whole experience messes with your head..... I too feel that I've dealt with it all well so far, apart from a massive wobble last week when it became apparent my children weren't coping as well as I'd thought they were. But chemo is scaring me. Re sore veins, my oncologist has agreed to me having a Picc line. There wasn't time for me to get it done before tomorrow, but I'll have it done ahead of next time if I have any problems. That's put my mind at rest a bit. I'm sorry you're finding it so hard, it may be a cumulation of everything that's happened as you've been strong for so long. Is there a treat that you can plan just ahead of your next chemo, something to look forward to and take your focus away from the inevitable, I know this works for lots of people. I'm planning on doing it for round 2, as we took the boys to Alton Towers this weekend and it did us all the world of good taking our minds of tomorrow. You will feel better, probably as the day goes on. Hopefully some ladies who are further on in their treatment will be along to reassure you too. Stay strong, big (((hugs))) S xx
Posts.Title: FEC and hair loss

Posts.Content: Hi Jelly, A friend text me this evening asking how I'd been today. I've been a bit down since my third chemo and my reply was "missing the person I used to be"..... I'm not sure she understood, and I couldn't really explain. This summarises it perfectly. Thanks for sharing. üòö
Posts.Title: The Spoon Theory

Posts.Content: I was at the hospital yesterday and my BCN referred me to the consultant for a quick exam..... All a bit spur of the moment, so he wasn't expecting me. Turns out it was my surgeon who I'd met a couple of times and had operated on me 10 days previously. It was obvious he didn't recognise me, as he started asking me questions etc. As I took my top off, and lay down...... His eyes went to the breast he'd operated on and he suddenly exclaimed "I recognise you!" It's the first time I've been recognised by my breast! Perhaps you had to be there, but it made me laugh!
Posts.Title: Made me smile.....

Posts.Content: I love the buff wear as they are quite versatile for a casual look. I've found an almost identical product at a third of the price on EBay. Search for Beechfield Morf and there's lots of colours to chose from at ¬£3.49, free p&p Xx
Posts.Title: Reasonable priced Scarves and Hats

Posts.Content: Hi Highland Mum.... You sound as if you've got the right attitude to get through chemo. It's not pain sailing, but like SaxxyD says - its doable. I'm a third of the way through.... I'll be halfway there after next next Wednesday:-) Keep your sense of humour and do get booked onto a Look Good Feel Better session.... It was just the tonic I needed shortly after chemo no. 2! Keep strong:-) S xxx
Posts.Title: Just told I need chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi, I've been thinking the same. Had surgery on 11th July, and still have what looks like a blue smartie on my nipple! It has faded, but is still quite pronounced. S x
Posts.Title: Blue/green dye from Sentinel Node Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Earls, I reacted badly to FEC, so was taken off of it and get 5 TC (docetaxel / cYclophosphomide) -lucky me! I was the same as Suzy. Had chemo on Weds and was ok until Sat. I too was in tears Sunday eve. I didn't have tramadol (might ask for some next time) but when I got up on Monday, the pain had almost disappeared. I just had a blinding headache and felt very tired. The only lasting side effect for me, this first time, is tiredness.... But my red blood count is very low so that is probably why. For me docetaxel was better than FEC.... Pain better than continual, uncontrollable vomiting. What a choice to have eh!? üòù S xxxx
Posts.Title: HOW LONG!

Posts.Content: Just to update. Ordered from Farmaline (in Belgium) on Saturday, they processed order Monday and I received it today, Wednesday. Pretty fantastic service üòÉ Let's hope the product does what it says on the tin.üôå S xxxxx
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: Wow, what a find! My nails still look ok, but I'm a few days behind you. Yesterday went out and bought some really good hand cream because the tips of my fingers were getting sore, as if I'd been mixing cement with them...... Not that I've ever mixed cement, but it's weird that is how it feels! I'm about I google now, for the iChat reasons.... To see if I can find evonail in the uk:-)

Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: Hi Lorraine, I'm using Evonail too. You have to remove nail varnish before applying, and as you have to apply it every day, guess its not practical to wear it on top.üíÖ I had tiny traces of nail varnish on my toes when I first apples Evonail and it went kind of 'jellyish'. I'm on my 5th chemo (4th tax) next Weds and my nails are looking goodüòÄüòÄ S xx üòúApologies there are no paragraphs, this site doesn't like ipadsüòù
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: Hi Squirrel, welcome to the site, but sorry you have to be here. üòî If you have chemo for BC, you will lose your hair. We all dread this and it is emotional...... but lots of us find its quite liberating. You can get really good wigs and there are some lovely hats and scarves, it won't be as bad as you imagineüòâ Re losing your nails, this will depend on the chemo you have. One of the most common chemos in the UK is FEC. This doesn't seem to affect your nails. Another common chemo, often given after FEC is Taxatore, also know as docetaxel. This is the one that can affect your nails, causing ridges and lifting to the extent that some people lose some nails during or just after chemo. üò£ Like Eider, I've used Evonail and have managed to keep healthy looking nails. Some ladies paint their nails with dark nail varnish, which they say works too. Apparently it is UV light that causes the damage to nails when you're on Tax, so i'd think that acrylic nails might not be a good idea as they are dried under uv light (?)..... I don't really know the answer but your oncologist will be able to tell you, and it is worth asking. If you can keep them it might make you feel a little more like 'you' as you go through the treatment. It will be ok, it is doable..... Let us know how you get on üòä
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: KeyFeatures, I've found a little Evonail goes a long way. I reckon my bottle will last for my 5 TAX..... Just, fingers crossed
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: An update on my nails. I'm now day 7 of Tax number 2 (of 5), and have been using Evonail since the week before my second dose. My nails are still strong and healthy. No ridges, no lifting, no splitting. My hands are still very dry and the tips of my fingers are a bit sore, but I'm using industrial strength hand cream on them, which is keeping it manageable. My onc asked me last week if I had experienced any problems with my nails, I mentioned this product. He raised his eyebrows but didn't 'pooh pooh' it. Infact he worte the name down on his pad and asked me to let him know what I thought when I'd finished treatement. Seems to be working so far is all I can report :-) S xx
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage
